sub_topic: Determining the convergence of a Fourier series
message_1: Consider the function $f(x) = x^3$ defined on $[-\pi, \pi]$. Find the Fourier series of $f(x)$ and determine whether it converges pointwise to $f(x)$ for all $x\in [-\pi, \pi]$.
message_2:
To find the Fourier series of the function $f(x) = x^3$ on the interval $[-\pi, \pi]$, we need to compute the Fourier coefficients $a_n$ and $b_n$ for $n \geq 0$ using the following formulas:

$$a_n = \frac{1}{\pi} \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} f(x) \cos(nx) dx$$
$$b_n = \frac{1}{\pi} \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} f(x) \sin(nx) dx$$

Since $f(x) = x^3$ is an odd function, all the $a_n$ coefficients will be zero. So, we only need to compute the $b_n$ coefficients:

$$b_n = \frac{1}{\pi} \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} x^3 \sin(nx) dx$$

We can compute this integral using integration by parts. Let $u = x^3$ and $dv = \sin(nx) dx$. Then, $du = 3x^2 dx$ and $v = -\frac{1}{n}\cos(nx)$. Applying integration by parts:

$$\int x^3 \sin(nx) dx = -\frac{1}{n}x^3\cos(nx) - \int -\frac{1}{n}(3x^2\cos(nx)) dx$$

Now, we apply integration by parts again. Let $w = 3x^2$ and $dz = \cos(nx) dx$. Then, $dw = 6x dx$ and $z = \frac{1}{n}\sin(nx)$. Applying integration by parts:

$$\int 3x^2 \cos(nx) dx = \frac{1}{n}(3x^2\sin(nx)) - \int \frac{1}{n}(6x\sin(nx)) dx$$

Now, we apply integration by parts one more time. Let $p = 6x$ and $dq = \sin(nx) dx$. Then, $dp = 6 dx$ and $q = -\frac{1}{n}\cos(nx)$. Applying integration by parts:

$$\int 6x \sin(nx) dx = -\frac{1}{n}(6x\cos(nx)) - \int -\frac{1}{n}(6\cos(nx)) dx$$

$$\int 6x \sin(nx) dx = -\frac{1}{n}(6x\cos(nx)) + \frac{6}{n^2}\sin(nx)$$

Now, we substitute back into our previous integrals:

$$\int x^3 \sin(nx) dx = -\frac{1}{n}x^3\cos(nx) + \frac{3}{n}\int x^2 \cos(nx) dx$$

$$\int x^3 \sin(nx) dx = -\frac{1}{n}x^3\cos(nx) + \frac{3}{n^2}(3x^2\sin(nx)) - \frac{9}{n^2}\int x \sin(nx) dx$$

$$\int x^3 \sin(nx) dx = -\frac{1}{n}x^3\cos(nx) + \frac{3}{n^2}(3x^2\sin(nx)) - \frac{9}{n^2}\left(-\frac{1}{n}(6x\cos(nx)) + \frac{6}{n^2}\sin(nx)\right)$$

Now, we compute the definite integral:

$$b_n = \frac{1}{\pi} \left[ -\frac{1}{n}x^3\cos(nx) + \frac{3}{n^2}(3x^2\sin(nx)) - \frac{9}{n^2}\left(-\frac{1}{n}(6x\cos(nx)) + \frac{6}{n^2}\sin(nx)\right) \right]_{-\pi}^{\pi}$$

Since $\cos(n\pi) = (-1)^n$ and $\sin(n\pi) = 0$, we get:

$$b_n = \frac{1}{\pi} \left[ -\frac{9}{n^2}\left(-\frac{1}{n}(6\pi(-1)^n)\right) \right] - \frac{1}{\pi} \left[ -\frac{9}{n^2}\left(-\frac{1}{n}(-6\pi(-1)^n)\right) \right]$$

$$b_n = \frac{1}{\pi} \left[ \frac{54\pi(-1)^n}{n^3} \right] - \frac{1}{\pi} \left[ \frac{54\pi(-1)^n}{n^3} \right] = \frac{108\pi(-1)^n}{n^3\pi}$$

$$b_n = \frac{108(-1)^n}{n^3}$$

Thus, the Fourier series of $f(x) = x^3$ is given by:

$$f(x) \sim \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{108(-1)^n}{n^3} \sin(nx)$$

Now, we need to determine whether the Fourier series converges pointwise to $f(x)$ for all $x \in [-\pi, \pi]$. Since $f(x)$ is an odd function and has continuous derivatives of all orders on $[-\pi, \pi]$, its Fourier series converges pointwise to $f(x)$ for all $x \in [-\pi, \pi]$.
